sn24.19:4.2: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:
sn24.19:4.3: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”
sn24.19:4.4: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn24.19:5.1: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
sn24.19:5.2: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’
sn24.19:5.7: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
sn24.19:5.8: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’
sn24.19:6.1: What do you think, mendicants? Is form permanent or impermanent?”
sn24.19:6.3: “But without grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
sn24.19:6.4: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”
sn24.19:6.7: “And so, when suffering exists, because of grasping suffering and insisting on suffering, the view arises:
sn24.19:6.8: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’
sn24.19:6.18: “And so, when suffering exists, because of grasping suffering and insisting on suffering, the view arises:
sn24.19:6.19: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’”
